factoid: Prince Andrew fell on his back.

Prince Andrew hoped to see whether the cannon had been captured or saved.
Prince Andrew saw nothing.
Above Prince Andrew there was nothing but the sky.
The sky above Prince Andrew was lofty.
The sky above Prince Andrew was not clear yet.
The sky above Prince Andrew was immeasurably lofty.
Gray clouds were gliding slowly across the sky above Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew thought the sky was quiet, peaceful, and solemn.
Prince Andrew thought the sky was not at all as when he ran.
Prince Andrew thought the sky was not as when they ran shouting and fighting.
Prince Andrew thought the sky was not as when the gunner and the Frenchman with frightened and angry faces struggled for the mop.

Prince Andrew was happy to have found the lofty sky at last.

Prince Andrew believed all is falsehood.
Prince Andrew believed only the infinite sky is real.
Prince Andrew believed there is nothing but the infinite sky.
Prince Andrew believed even the infinite sky does not exist but there is nothing but quiet and peace.
Prince Andrew thanked God.
The right flank was commanded by Prince Bagratión.
At nine o’clock the battle had not yet begun.
Prince Bagratión did not wish to agree to Dolgorúkov’s demand to commence the action.
Prince Bagratión wished to avert responsibility from himself.
Prince Bagratión proposed to Dolgorúkov that a messenger be sent to inquire of the commander in chief.
The distance between the two flanks was more than six miles.
The messenger was very likely to be killed.
Finding the commander in chief would be very difficult.
Prince Bagratión would not be able to return before evening if the messenger was not killed.
Prince Bagratión cast his large, expressionless, sleepy eyes around his suite.
Rostóv had a boyish face that was breathless with excitement and hope.
Rostóv was the first to catch Prince Bagratión’s eye.
Prince Bagratión sent Rostóv.
Rostóv asked Prince Bagratión whether he should meet His Majesty before meeting the commander in chief.
Rostóv gestured with his hand to his cap.
Dolgorúkov told Prince Bagratión that he could give the message to His Majesty.
Dolgorúkov hurriedly interrupted Prince Bagratión.
Rostóv was relieved from picket duty.
Rostóv had a few hours’ sleep before morning.
Rostóv felt cheerful.
Rostóv felt bold.
Rostóv felt resolute.
Rostóv had elasticity of movement.
Rostóv had faith in his good fortune.
Rostóv had a state of mind that made everything seem possible, pleasant, and easy.
Rostóv’s wishes were being fulfilled that morning.

Rostóv was orderly to the bravest general.
Rostóv was going with a message to Kutúzov.
Rostóv was perhaps going with a message to the sovereign himself.
The morning was bright.
Rostóv had a good horse under him.
Rostóv’s heart was full of joy and happiness.
Rostóv received an order.
Rostóv gave his horse the rein.
Rostóv galloped along the line.
Rostóv rode along the line of Prince Bagratión’s troops.
Prince Bagratión’s troops had not yet advanced into action.
Prince Bagratión’s troops were standing motionless.

Rostóv noticed signs of preparation for battle in the region occupied by Uvárov’s cavalry.
Rostóv passed Uvárov’s cavalry.
Rostóv clearly heard the sound of cannon and musketry ahead of him.
The firing grew louder and louder.
In the fresh morning air, a roll of volleys of musketry from the slopes of the hill before Pratzen was heard.
The roll of volleys of musketry was interrupted by frequent reports of cannon.
Several cannon shots were not separated from one another but merged into a general roar.
Rostóv could see puffs of musketry smoke that seemed to chase one another down the hillsides.
Rostóv could see clouds of cannon smoke rolling.
Rostóv could see clouds of cannon smoke spreading.
Rostóv could see clouds of cannon smoke mingling with one another.
Rostóv could see moving masses of infantry by the gleam of bayonets visible through the smoke.
Rostóv could see narrow lines of artillery with green caissons.
Rostóv stopped his horse for a moment on a hillock.
Rostóv tried to see what was going on.
Rostóv could not understand or make out anything of what was happening.
In the smoke men of some sort were moving about.
In front and behind moved lines of troops.
It was impossible to make out why, whither, and who the men were.

The sights and sounds had no intimidating effect on Rostóv.
The sights and sounds stimulated Rostóv’s energy.
The sights and sounds stimulated Rostóv’s determination.
